Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Fiber Sensors Networks for Crude Oil Migration Monitoring In Ocean

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

1054652 (EAGER)
Peng Chen
University of Pittsburg

The Deepwater Horizon oil spills in the Gulf of Mexico has become the most damaging environmental catastrophe in the US history. The failures for scientists and engineers to promptly stop the rupture and to swiftly evaluate the environmental damage highlight a number of daunting technical challenges related to deepwater resource exploration, pollution monitoring, and ecological conservation. In this EAGAR project, a distributed sensing network based on fiber optical sensing technology is investigated and designed for in-situ measurement of subsurface oil distribution and migration. Fiber grating sensors will be fabricated in short sections of high-attenuation fibers. Each fiber sensor will be coated with oil-affinitive porous nano-materials. Once it encounters oil droplets, the porous materials will absorb oil droplet, which leads to the increase of refractive index change and absorption in porous layers. Using wavelength division multiplexing, a large number of fiber sensors can be monitored by a single interrogation instrument.

The proposed research will provide powerful and low-cost sensing tools to monitor three-dimensional oil pollution distribution and migration under ocean currents. The effectiveness of the clean-up efforts and long-term impact of oil spills to ocean ecology can be rapidly evaluated, rectified, and improved. This project will also impact the sustainability education at the University of Pittsburgh by providing unique teaching opportunities to students in terms of technological skills, professional ethnics, and environmental responsibilities.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research program developed a unique fiber optical sensing technology that can measure chemical species such as pollutants and physical parameters such as pressure, temperature, water levels, and flow with high spatial resolutions in harsh environments.

In this research, we used fiber optical cables as platforms for both optical power delivery and sensor integrations. To measure targeted chemical species, functional sensory nanomateriels with appropriate pore sizes, dopants, and refractive index changes have been developed and integrated on optical fibers with special geometrical shapes (D-shape). Advanced fiber optical interrogation schemes such as Optical Frequency Domain Reflectometry was used to measure fiber sensor responses to targeted chemical species with 1-cm spatial resolutions.

Using other specialty fibers such as air-hole microstructured fibers, our research team also developed distributed physical sensing schemes to measure flow, pressure, water levels, and temperature with 1-cm spatial resolution or better. Optical power carried in optical fibers were used to adjust the sensitivities and functionalities of the fiber sensors, which enabled active measurements.

Using this robust sensor technology, researchers from the University of Pittsburgh demonstrated distributed chemical and physical measurements with high spatial resolution across a wide temperature ranges from the room temperature to 700C and from a pressure range from 15 psi to 2500 psi.

The outcome of this research provides scientists and engineers powerful sensing tools for both chemical and physical measurements. It will have broad applications for environmental monitoring in ocean and on land, down-hole oil and gas exploration, applications in fossil fuels, bio-mass, and nuclear energy generations, and others.

Scientific results generated from this program have been disseminated in 11 scentific papers. All of them are available on the internet. One U.S. patent is also submitted (http://www.freepatentsonline.com/y2014/0321798.html). Three engineering Ph.Ds have been produced through supports of this grant, who have become experts in telecommications, medical, and defense industries in the U.S.
